issues.description: The problem statement's class diagram and text expect a Stock method named emptyStock(): void (used to clear the inventory). The template Stock class instead provides a method named clearInventory(), while the reference solution implements emptyStock(). This name mismatch between the problem description, the template, and the solution is structural: students reading the UML or following the spec will look for emptyStock(), but the starter code exposes clearInventory(), which may cause confusion or compilation/signature mismatches when tests or students expect emptyStock().
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template's Stock API match the problem statement and solution by renaming the template method clearInventory() to emptyStock(), or add an emptyStock() method that delegates to clearInventory(). Update any documentation/comments accordingly so the method name is consistent across problem statement, template, and solution.

issues.description: The Stock class method for clearing the inventory is referred to as 'emptyStock()' in the problem statement UML and implemented as 'emptyStock()' in the solution, but the template repository provides a method named 'clearInventory()' instead. This inconsistent identifier for the same conceptual operation (clearing the stock) can confuse students when they map the problem requirements to the starter code and the reference solution and may cause them to search for or implement the wrong method name.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method name consistent across artifacts. Rename the template's clearInventory() method to emptyStock(), or add an emptyStock() wrapper that delegates to clearInventory(), so the template, problem statement, and solution all refer to the same method name (emptyStock). This preserves conceptual alignment and reduces student confusion.
